0.text: Pagano: Ok, I think I'll go ahead and get started

3.text: and if you haven't gotten your coffee yet

4.text: feel free get to up and get some coffee.

8.text: But I welcome you here ealry in this morning. It's kind of a cold day.

12.text: I think thats why everyone was hurdling around huddling around the coffee in the back of the room.

16.text: But I'm really glad that you're here. My favorite people are here this morning.

19.text: Uh, a lot has happened since the last time we talked.

23.text: Uh, including a wonderful Thanksgiving- four days off.

26.text: How many enjoyed four days off? Yes.

30.text: How many talked about politics at the table?

36.text:
We started to but then someone mentioned 
the watery mash potatoes, which I made.

41.text:
And that got us way off subject and 
we kept talking about the potatoes instead of other things,

46.text: which was good for our family.

48.text: So anyway, I'm glad you all hade a restful break.

51.text: I'm assuming you did because we have a little bit of a marothon here; sprint.

55.text:
I guess a sprint towards the end. 
So uh, we're exicted to have the opportunity to do that.

60.text: So, I have lots to talk to you about. So I'll talk kind of quickly 'cause this is advertised as a Town Hall

65.text: that would leave you to believe that we will get both of us to talk  so I want to be truth in advertising and have a chance for that.

72.text: But I do want to tell you what's going on in the Chancellor's office.

75.text: And I also want to preface this, by you'll recognize some of these slides

79.text: because some of slides these things that we're going to talk about haven't changed a whole lot,

83.text: but I'm going to remind you about them

85.text:
'cause it's-it's seldom that I go to a meeting where 
where everybody knows everthing that is going on.

90.text:
Because I know you all have other things to do besides 
coming to my town halls.

94.text: So I apologize in advance if you hear things a second time.

99.text: So before we get started, we have two special guests here today.

104.text: I'm probably going to embarass them, by putting their pictures on here.

107.text:
But we have a old colleage, not an "old" colleague. 
[audience laughs]

112.text: A previous colleague of mine from Montana State, Nancy Cornwell is here.

118.text: Uh, these two ladies are part of the ACE Fellows Program.

122.text: Uh, and they are also friends of Anne Bartlett, our new dean of IAS,  who was an Ace fellow, I think a year ago.

131.text: I think it was a year ago at Portland State;

133.text: one of our kind of sister institutions.

135.text:
And knows them and invited them to our campus. 
We are really glad to have them here.

140.text: Uh, Chia, is a professor in the department of

144.text:
Biomedical, Chemical and Environmental Engineering. 
Uh, at the University of Cincinnati.

149.text:
But she's placed in Duckville- I mean in the University of Oregon. 
[audience laughs]

153.text: Uh, and you're placed at the College in New Jersey.

157.text: Beautiful campus- I had the opportunity to go there a couple of years ago.

160.text: Why don't you stand up so that they can see you.

166.text: So uh, they had the privildege of staying at the Murono last night.

169.text:
And uh, they're seeing Tacoma and 
they're seeing some of uh, other sister schools around the coast.

173.text: But they'll be here all day. So reach out and talk to them;

176.text: tell them about your campus and we're glad to have them here.

179.text: Okay, what are we going to do today?

181.text: Well, we're gonna debrief what has happened since the last time

184.text: we were all here. We're gunna talk about new organizational development.

188.text:
Not a whole lot has happened in that arena 
but we're going to see where we are.

191.text: We're going to talk more about the race and equity series.

194.text: And I'll answer some questions along those lines.

197.text: A lot of people have questions about what's going on and what's gonna happen next.

200.text: Uh, a little bit about the law school.

203.text: Uh, we don't know a whole lot more, but I'm going to tell you what I do know.

206.text: Uh, enrollment snapshot, where we landed, and where we plan to go.

210.text:
We'll talk a little about budget development, 
'cause that's important to all of us as we move forward.

214.text:
Uh,we'll talk about where the strategic planning-
our charting charting our courses,

219.text: uh.. right now, what phase that's in and implementation of that.

223.text: We'll talk briefly about the campaign launch,

226.text: and then we'll have questions in discussions. So everybody ready?

230.text: I can tell-you're ready. Here we go.

234.text: Okay, what happened since we we're here before?

236.text: I don't know about all of you but, October was a blur.

240.text:
We had so much going on, on our campus in October; 
and if we weren't doing it, we were getting ready for it.

245.text: The first couple of weeks we were getting ready for it.

247.text:
But I felt like everything worked like a charm 
because the good people we have here responsible for these things.

254.text: But we love it when we have the Board of Regents here.  Uh, that was at the beginning of the month.

259.text:
They were here right in this room. 
Uh, for lunch on the 13th, uh, we had some excellent presentations.

265.text: Uh, Dr. Lavitt had a chance to talk about what's going on in the faculty hiring process.

270.text: Uh, I was really proud of that presentation.

272.text:
We're doing a lot of good things, 
and then we talked about the strategic plan.

275.text: And you were very well represented, not necessarily by me,

278.text: but by professor Bonnie Becker, Amanda Figueroa- uh talked, and also Carl Smith talked.

284.text: And told the Regents about why we are doing the strategic plan,

288.text: who the students are that we serve in the strategic plan,  and about the implementation.

293.text: They were very impressed- I think every single one of them sought me out individually and told me how impressed they were with our plan.

301.text: And uh, one, the chair, I don't know if this was an insult or a compliment but he came and kinda put his arm around me and said-

308.text: boy this is a wonderful plan.

309.text: I can tell it was done by an engineer. I thought, oh my goodness!

314.text: That's the last thing I wanted, because I don't want it to be Mark's plan,

316.text: I wanted it to be our plan. But I think he meant well.

319.text: He meant that it was very well organized; so that was a compliment- wasn't it?

323.text:
Yes, yes it was. 
[audience chants yes]

326.text: So that was a positive day. I really felt good about that day.

328.text: And they actually got a sneak prea-peak to our strategic plan kick- off,

335.text:
I, of course, enjoyed that event. Uh, 
I know that my friend Abraham enjoyed that event.

341.text: He- he sent me a telegram and told me that he enjoyed that event.

345.text: We also had a race and equity kick-off.

348.text: That was very well attended, thanks to Sharon and her staff for uh,

352.text: attracting Bree Newsome here. Bree stayed a long time. She really engaged with our students;

358.text:
Uh, we had more than just this debate. 
We had several debates,

362.text: we hosted debates on campus, we hosted some debates off campus.

366.text:
And I know Dean Bartlett attended several of those 
on the behalf of her school.

370.text: The one was very well attended, the same night night as Bree Newsome.

374.text: It ended up being a very close race. A race full of integrity;

379.text:
I was proud to host that on our campus. 
We launched the campaign- when I say we, I didn't have a whole lot to do with it.

386.text: But I rode on the bus to the campaign launch.

388.text: Uh, but I think that is the first time- you know I commute to Seattle  quite a bit;

393.text: maybe once or twice a week. Sometimes- this week I don't have to go at all.

398.text: But often, I go there once or twice a week.

400.text:
I think that was the first time ever in my commute to Seattle, 
I had champagne.

408.text:
I guess it was on the way home we had the champagne. 
But that was a great event.

412.text: I was very proud to be a University of Washington employee.

416.text: We had our niece with us, who has applied to the graduate school at the other UW- up at the Seattle campus.

421.text: She's applied for the Ph.D program.

423.text:
And she went to that event with us and 
when she got done, she thought, my goodness!

427.text:
If I was on the edge of deciding whether 
or not I want to come here, I'm coming here if they invite me.

432.text: That's a long shot to see if she will get invited, but we'll see.

435.text: But anyway, the Native American supposing was really outstanding;

440.text:
I only had an opportunity to be there for about an hour, 
but what I saw was good. Sharon assures me it was very well attended

446.text:
and we will like to have more of you all attend to 
showcase our campus, they took a tour.

450.text: That was here and then the annual faculty appreciation staff pie day.

455.text:
You know, uh, ladies, if you had come last wednesday, 
you could of have had pie rather than come to the Town Hall.

461.text:
So next year, the next time you visit, 
you will know.

463.text: Also, the Apple Cup. Who watched the Apple Cup?

467.text:
Yes! We did very well, on that catapulted with us, 
if you read the paper today, we are in that fourth spot.

474.text:
In the college championship series. 
So its up to us, we have Colorado this Friday.

483.text:
If we beat Colorado there's no way that they could leave us out 
of that championship series.

486.text:
What we want now, is to move up to third 
so that we don't have to play Alabama first.

494.text: Okay. Leadership development. Well, I don't know a bunch about these searches-

499.text:
I did have the opportunity to charge this first search 
about a month ago. But they're all in good hands.

504.text:
They're all kind of in the quiet phase right now. 
Melissa charged the other two searches- the two Inaugural Dean searches.

512.text:
But I did have the opportuniuty to visit with 
Alberto Pimental and Ryan Krofert, our two consultants on these searches.

519.text:
They were at the same meeting I was at in 
Austin about two weeks ago.

523.text: They sought me out and they told me that its going really well.

527.text:
There is alot of excitement. The fact these are 
inagural deans is exciting people and getting alot of interest.

532.text:
And the fact that our student affaris person is
both enrollment services and student affairs,

540.text:
So I will look for positive things- and if you want to know 
more about these searches, talk to these people.

546.text: They are mostly in the room.

547.text:
They can tell you more about where they are, they 
can't violate the confidentiality of the searches,

550.text: but they can tell you what's going on, where they're at.

552.text:
We staged the interviews in the spring, or winter, 
in the winter, I don't know when- March.

560.text:
But they're staged so- is March Spring or Winter? It's both. It's both. 
[audience laughs]

567.text: We've got them so the interviews are gonna be like, several weeks. So we will have that search fatigue again by April.

577.text:
A couple other ones that aren't decided yet, 
but we need to get to work on.

581.text: I need to visit with Dr. Lavitt and the Executive Director of Global Affairs, it's in excellent hands right now

587.text:
professor Lisa Hoffman is leading that at interim basis. 
But she is going on subbatical.

592.text:
So uh, and I bet ya she goes on subbatical 
no matter what I ask her to do. She's going on subbatical.

598.text:
So we need to think about what we are going to do with that 
and also, uh the Associate Vice Cancellor for Educational Outreach-

604.text: that search failed last summer- and we got to decide on that.

607.text:
And one reason why I really want to- to kind of accelerate 
this is our Federal Way patnership.

612.text: I've talked about this several times-

614.text: it's actually coming closer to furition right now. About ten of us are going there next Monday,

621.text: uh, and they got the report back which does show a need and an interest in the presence.

627.text: That's the big question- what does the UW Tacoma presence gonna be like?

632.text: Well whatever it's like, it's gonna be better than a WSU presence in Federal Way- I know that.

637.text: And I also know that we will do it in conjunction with Highline.

642.text: I have talked to the president of Highline several times- they're interested.

645.text: They were there before. So we will have some kind of joint presence-

647.text:
probably starting with a person, or maybe a shared person 
that would be in an office or maybe in a conference room.

655.text:
We could teach a couple courses there. 
We have alot of faculty that lives in Federal Way.

659.text:
Maybe there's a core class, or a general ed class 
that we could teach there on location and students from Federal Way

666.text: can go there that day. Or something- we don't know.

668.text: But, they want to have some kind of presence by fall 2018.

673.text:
So we got to get started doing that. 
And it is going to be UW Tacoma- not UW, UW Tacoma Federal Way.

681.text: How's that sounds? UW Tacoma Federal Way.

686.text: Alright, Law School. I'll show you the slide but I wont go through all the details.

691.text: But, its important to remember that several things have to be in place.

695.text:
First of all, we don't want a Law School project to interfere 
with the other things that we are doing.

702.text: We have a new strategic plan that we launched.

704.text: So if we want to do the Law School, we want to do it in conjunction with these in parallel.

708.text: Uh, we need to have the support, which we do of the UW and the UW Law School and all that.

712.text:
But, we also need to have a sizeable state 
allocation to do that. So, that's kind of the phase that we're at right now.

718.text:
But before we would ask for that, we have a 
feasibility study that is in progress and is just about finished.

725.text: I expect it any day now, we actually got pieces of it.

730.text:
One piece we got was on the admissions data for 
the other law schools in the State of Washington in this region.

738.text:
It's not robust- I have to tell you that right now. 
The admissions have been tight, it's competitive.

743.text:
Likewise, we have a study that was done that 
I've just seen the perliminary part of what the anticipated demand is

750.text: of students that are graduating from degrees that are thinking about law school

754.text:
and are from both public law firms or governmental 
law firms and private law firms- what their outlook is.

760.text:
Those things are not really robust, 
but we have to get the whole picture.

764.text: They also visited with many community supporters-

768.text:
the Tacoma community law foundation, they visited with tribes 
that are interested in having tribal law as a part of a law school here.

777.text: So I need to get the whole report and read the advantages,

780.text:
disadvantages, and risks and then we will have to 
make a desicion pretty soon- what the next steps will be.

785.text:
So hopefully, the next time we talk, I can 
tell you what we are anticipating in respects to the Law School.

794.text: Okay, the race and equity initiative- you recognized this slide before.

798.text:
And for our guest, the race and equity initiative is 
an initiative by our president that she launched when she was still interim president.

808.text: A little over a year ago now- probably a year and a half ago.

811.text:
She launched this initiative and when I talked in May, 
you may recall that I had a photograph of some chalk artwork on the sidewalk.

822.text:
Where the students had charged us to have more 
action than just the talk.

828.text: And that kind of affected me- that affected all of us.

830.text:
We wanted to start having action- although you 
know the race and equity initiative is designed to force the conversation.

837.text: To get us all talking about that.

839.text:
So uh, after I saw that in May, and we talked about it
then, you know we were all upset by this rapid series of things-

848.text:
of catastrophes that had happened in Orlando 
and the shootings that were rapidly happening after that.

854.text: It upset everybody and luckily, we have alot of people on campus who care;

858.text:
so Edd and Kathleen and several people quickly 
organized a standing together event.

865.text: And at the time, I was standing there listening to them talking

868.text: and could see all the people. And maybe you recognize yourself in that picture-

872.text: uh struggling with what to do as a campus.

875.text: So I stepped forward and said we'll commit to having a series of active discussions.

881.text: We'll decide what to do. We'll learn best practices.

885.text: We'll learn how to be- uh- activitsts in these areas that are important to us.

890.text: So I'm really glad that we started that because we have to prepare ourselves.

893.text: Now we know- like the boy scouts- we always need to be prepared in the higher education institution

899.text: and its all of our responsiblities to prepare ourselves daily for what's going on around us

903.text:
and  the world because our students are looking to 
us to know that. It doesn't matter if you are a professor, staff person, or what.

909.text: So, I'm glad we had that.

911.text: Uh, the outcome of that day, was the series of active discussions.

917.text: And Sharon has a group that has been working on this-

919.text:
I won't mention all the names but there are 
several of you in the crowd. They put together a series of events.

925.text: One event was Bree Newsome. And I'll talk about a couple other ones- pretty good.

930.text: Uh, so that is- that is great.

932.text: But we have to continue to worry about- or not wory about- but to do our actions.

937.text: We'll do the talks and we'll continue to learn,

940.text: but we have to do things.

941.text:
So, I'm proud of our campus- 
many various areas of our campus are doing alot of action.

945.text: Some I'll highlight a few of those. But also, one of the things that

950.text:
I'm most proud of is that we were already actively 
working on the strategic plan while all of this was going.

958.text: And it surrounds you right now.

960.text:
But I think I put a couple of them here. 
I can put all six of them up here. But the strategic plan that came out,

966.text:
uh, in June, right before these things were 
happening, really sets the stage for how I want- I hope you want-

977.text: UW Tacoma to respond to what's going on around us.

982.text:
And if you look at what we say- look at the first one- 
empowers students to achieve their dreams.

989.text:
Well, their dreams- I'm sure- aren't to put their head in 
a hole and worry about what's going on around them.

997.text:
They want to get the tools so that they can change 
what's going on around them-

1000.text:
if they don't like what's going on around them- 
through civil.. ya know,

1004.text:
well described processes. We don't want anarchy. 
We have a responsiblity to help our students-

1011.text: empower them to achieve their dreams.

1014.text: They got to do their work. They can't come to your class unprepared- those kinds of things.

1019.text:
But we said that. And we believe that still, 
we believed it before the election and we believe it after the election, likewise.

1026.text:
Equity, our statement on equity is very, very powerful.  
I choked up when I read this,

1033.text: "We are grounded in social justice and embrace the assets of our diverse communities."

1041.text: I learned this the first week I was here. I attended the conference with several of you -

1046.text:
Amanda was there, Sharon was there, and I was uh, 
introduced to some of these concepts.

1053.text: It's a wonderful campus that believes in these things.

1056.text:
Likewise, our culture, we charged ourselves with having 
a culture on this campus that is respectful, productive and inclusive.

1066.text: Tha- that's important for us. So what am I showing you this for?

1071.text: Well, as we were launching this at the strategic planning roll out,

1076.text:
when I was sitting there by aid thinking about all this, and 
Carl--where's Carl?--

1081.text: Carl got up thinking that he would get into trouble for going off script.

1086.text: Remember that? Oh man, he didn't get into trouble.

1089.text: I think he encouraged alot of us to think deeply about what we do.

1095.text: It changed kinda my thought process. Ya know,  I felt a whole lot better about UW Tacoma that day.

1100.text: Because I know Carl- I work closely with Carl.

1103.text: And he fortunately had the microphone- alot of you don't have the microphone.

1106.text: But I know alot of you share Carl's commitment to our students and uh, a lot of you- all of you do.

1115.text:
So I feel really good about our campus and you're 
gonna think this is really hokie.

1120.text: But I can't help that- I am kind of a hokie person.

1122.text:
Uh, but I am pretty narrow-minded when it comes to music. 
I've been a Neal Young and Bob Dylan fan for about forty years.

1132.text: And both of them have been around- they're both still kickin' too.

1136.text: Do we have any Neil Young and Bob Dylan fans in the room?

1138.text:
Alright! Yes, yes! And I don't deviate much but um, 
I married Kelly- Kelly is not a Bob Dylan or a Neil Young fan.

1148.text: She is a Tori Amos fan. And I've learned to like Tori.

1152.text:
And Tori actually played a few lines of a Neil Young 
song at her concert because I asked her to.

1159.text:
I can't believe she did that so I'm a Tori Amos fan now too. 
I'll tell you about that later, but not in front of all of you at one time.

1165.text:
Anyway, uh, I lived in Montana and it's complicated 
when you live in Montana when all your relatives are at other places.

1173.text: She's shaking her head- Nancy Knows.

1175.text: Uh, so I was driving with my son, who lived in Montana, to Colorado-

1179.text: I am getting somewhere with this point, by the way.

1181.text: But I'm going off on a story-

1183.text:
so I was driving to Colorado to get my daughter and we 
were all gonna fly to Illinois to see my parents

1188.text:
and then go to Kelly's house for Christmas yet 
'cause I wasn't married yet.

1191.text: Kelly and I were just an item. We weren't married yet.

1194.text:
But anyway, my daughter hadn't done her 
shopping yet and wanted to buy something for Kelly,

1198.text: so she brought Kelly an Avett Brothers CD.

1203.text: Not many. We have a few here. I never heard of them either,

1207.text: but my daughter wanted to buy it for my girlfriend- at the time.

1210.text:
So I thought that was really sweet. 
It became one of our favorite albums-

1213.text: uh, Kelly and I have loved that album.

1214.text: It's uh, " I and Love and You."

1217.text:
Have you ever heard that song? You haven't heard that song? 
[audience laughs]

1220.text: Oh it's such a sweet song. Sing it! She says sing it!

1223.text:
That's the name of the album and that's the- 
the- what do you call it when the song is the same as the...

1228.text:
it's like... the sound! Yea, it's the lead song. 
But then there is another song on there about January wedding.

1233.text:
Well, Kelly's brother is- uh,uh,um... 
a musician and he remaked that to July wedding and sang it at our wedding.

1240.text: That's how much we love the Avett Brothers now.

1241.text:
But anyway, they have another song and 
I'm going to put it up here- and don't make fun of me-

1245.text:
I'm going to put it up here. But these words, of this song, 
is called a "Head Full of Doubt," really moved me to what's going on right now.

1253.text:
So I'm not going to sing it- I could. 
[audience laughs]

1255.text: 'Cause I listen to it all the time.

1257.text: Uh, "but there is a darkness upon us flooded in light

1259.text: In the fine print they tell us what's wrong and what's right

1262.text: And it comes in black and it comes in white

1264.text: And I'm frightened by those that don't see it...

1267.text: When nothing is owed or deserved or expected

1271.text: And your life doesn't change by the man that's elected

1274.text: If you're loved by someone, you're never rejected.

1277.text: Decide what to be and go be it."

1279.text: Man this, this right here, says a lot to me about our students.

1283.text:
We need to help our students decide what to be 
and help them go be it. Um, and I'm not just kidding-

1290.text: that's kind of what we need to do everyday.

1293.text: Um, how many think that's hokie?

1298.text: It's important. So that's what I would like us to do as a campus-

1301.text:
is you know, not romantically love our students, 
[audience laughs]

1305.text: but you could tell from Carl's comment,

1313.text: And I know many of you do too.

1316.text: Paul is standing there smiling, but I know Paul loves our students.

1318.text: And they need to understand that.

1321.text:
Everyday they need to come here and feel 
like this is a sanctuary, where they are safe.

1326.text:
And that will improve their learning. 
You know, Melissa is very worried about our retention-

1330.text: and I got her working on that.

1331.text: And so is Jill and the committee- working on retention.

1334.text: But alot can be solved if we help our students know they are appreciated.

1339.text:
We make safe places for them to study here, 
where they like to be here- all those kinds of things.

1343.text: So, that's what I want to lead our campus to do.

1346.text:
I was thinking too you know, I have a beautiful view 
of Commencement Bay at our house. We love our house.

1350.text:
And some mornings- you know how that fog sets in 
and just covers everything and you could almost feel it?

1355.text: Our students should feel us lovin' on them when they're here.

1359.text: If we can be like fog, that's what we should do-

1367.text:
So now you ought to be proud- you have a chancellor 
that dresses up like Abe Lincoln and quotes songs that nobody knows.

1375.text: So uh, quickly I'll just show some of the things that we are doing.

1380.text:
The active discussions are going well. 
I think you will get a great announcement today.

1385.text:
I'm really thrilled with our Paulsen Lecture Commitee's choice, 
for our lecture this year.

1390.text:
Look who we've got coming -the bad thing about it,  
it's not till May.

1394.text: You know, my goodness, can't you move it up till December 3rd?

1398.text:
That wouldn't work. But anyway, we are co-sponsoring it 
with the Broadway Center; it's at Pantages.

1406.text: Of the "Hashtag BlackLivesMatter" and a Political analyst.

1410.text:
I know you want to be there and by putting it in Pantages, 
we can have twice as many people in there.

1415.text:
It's a great event, and that will be kind of the 
capstone at the end of the year. Now, there are other events,

1419.text: Sharon and the team have been organizing the other events.

1422.text: Many of you have been going to them.

1423.text: Right now, they're concentrating on the event in January.

1427.text: I don't know what the date's solidified, but they're working towards January 9th.

1431.text:
Uh, to talk about public discourse; what the laws are. 
Uh- with um- you know, free speech,

1438.text:
hate speech- all those complicated things; 
we need to understand those if we're gonna behave in a civil, respectful way.

2992.text: You know, of this country that's made up of all kinds of people

3021.text: I don't know what else to say Linda. I'm probably just as confused

3025.text: about the climate as you and everybody else. We'll take each day.

3056.text: Well, these are really good questions and I'm glad you all came here today.
